}}</ref> Mubarak and his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDP)]] government maintained one-party rule under a continuous state of emergency since 1981.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's government earned the support of the West and a continuation of annual aid from the United States by maintaining policies of suppression towards [[Islamic militants]] and peace with [[Israel]].<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" /> Hosni Mubarak was often compared to an Egyptian [[pharaoh]] by the media and by some of his harsher critics due to his authoritarian rule.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/History-s-crossroads/748326 |title=Historyâs crossroads |publisher=Indianexpress.com |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
}}</ref> Mubarak and his [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party (NDP)]] government maintained one-party rule under a continuous state of emergency since 1981.<ref name="Hosni Mubarak">{{cite web|author=|url=http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/hosni_mubarak/index.html|title=Hosni Mubarak|work=The New York Times |date=8 March 2010|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak's government earned the support of the West and a continuation of annual aid from the United States by maintaining policies of suppression towards [[Islamic militants]] and peace with [[Israel]].<ref name="Hosni Mubarak" /> Hosni Mubarak was often compared to an Egyptian [[pharaoh]] by the media and by some of his harsher critics due to his authoritarian rule.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/History-s-crossroads/748326 |title=Historyâs crossroads |publisher=Indianexpress.com |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
â   â
===Emergency law===
  â
{{main|Emergency law in Egypt}}
  â
An [[Emergency law in Egypt|emergency law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">{{cite web
  â
| url=http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162
  â
| title=Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)
  â
| work={{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]
  â
| accessdate=2 April 2010
  â
}}</ref> and continuously in effect since President Sadat's 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalized,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/|title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States|date=26 March 2004|accessdate=30 January 2011|last=Shehata|first=Samer|work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organizations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw" /> The Mubarak government has cited the threat of [[terrorism]] in order to extend the emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008" /> claiming that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo [[parliamentary elections]] and suppressed the group through actions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{Cite book|last= Caraley|first= Demetrios|title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy|publisher=[[Academy of Political Science]]|year= 2004|month= April|isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> This has led to the imprisonment of activists without trials,<ref name="Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation">{{cite web|author=Choney, Suzanne|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41285248/ns/technology_and_science-tech_and_gadgets/|title=Egyptian bloggers brave police intimidation|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[MSNBC]]}}</ref> illegal undocumented hidden detention facilities,<ref name="Mayer">{{cite web|url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/30/061030ta_talk_mayer|title=The C.I.A.'s Travel Agent|date= 30 October 2006|accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[The New Yorker]] |author=Mayer, Jane}}</ref><ref name="Kalla fakta">{{cite web|url=http://www.trojkan.se/temp/Reportage/KF_Extraordinary_Rendition/English_version/The%20Broken%20Promise%20-%20%20How%20we%20did%20it.doc|title=Striptease brevpapperl Agent|date= 18 May 2004|accessdate=28 January 2011|publisher=trojkan.se|author=Fakta, Kalla}}</ref> and rejecting university, mosque, and newspaper staff members based on their political inclination.<ref name="independents fight for hearts and minds">{{cite web|author=Shenker, Jack|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/nov/22/egypt-elections-muslim-brotherhood-ndp|title=Egyptian Elections: Independents Fight for Hearts and Minds in 'Fixed Ballot'|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=22 November 2010|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> A [[Egyptian parliamentary election, 2010|parliamentary election]] in December 2010 was preceded by a media crackdown, arrests, candidate bans (particularly of the Muslim Brotherhood), and allegations of fraud involving the near unanimous victory by the ruling party in parliament.<ref name="emerlaw" /> Human rights organizations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Press release]]|publisher=[[Amnesty International]]|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June: Joint Statement|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|date=29 June 2010|accessdate=4 February 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
 
=== Inheritance of Power ===
=== Inheritance of Power ===
Line 103: Line 94:
In September 2004 several political groups (most are unofficial), on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate.<ref>[http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm]<font color="blue">deadlink, 9 November 2010</font></ref>
In September 2004 several political groups (most are unofficial), on both the left and the right, announced their sharp opposition to the inheritance of power. They demanded political change and asked for a fair election with more than one candidate.<ref>[http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm http://mengos.net/events/04newsevents/egypt/september/9september04.htm]<font color="blue">deadlink, 9 November 2010</font></ref>
  +   +
===Emergency law===
  +
{{main|Emergency law in Egypt}}
  +
An [[Emergency law in Egypt|emergency law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">{{cite web

  +

  +
